problem_statement:
`jupyterlab.browser_check` is slow as it downloads browsers
## Description

On CI here and in extension-template we download a browser each time for browser check. We should improve CI to not waste dev time on it. We should cache to browser for this:

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/339c823c-0f6f-4f8d-a210-590efb88c89c)

and probably do not need to setup Firefox here anymore:

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/59bdc496-aa62-43ca-8b7c-2778fc1dfd12)

Since https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/pull/15117
test_patch:
diff --git a/.github/workflows/linuxtests.yml b/.github/workflows/linuxtests.yml
index d7949d883e52..3c790269c93e 100644
--- a/.github/workflows/linuxtests.yml
+++ b/.github/workflows/linuxtests.yml
@@ -54,8 +54,14 @@ jobs:
       - name: Base Setup
         uses: jupyterlab/maintainer-tools/.github/actions/base-setup@v1
 
-      - name: Setup firefox
-        uses: browser-actions/setup-firefox@latest
+      - name: Restore Playwright browsers cache
+        uses: actions/cache@v3
+        id: playwright-cache
+        with:
+          path: /home/runner/.cache/ms-playwright
+          key: playwright-browsers-${{ runner.os }}-v1
+          restore-keys: |
+            playwright-browsers-${{ runner.os }}-
 
       - name: Install dependencies
         env:

problem_statement:
Emit a signal when the file browser selected items changes
### Problem

Currently there is no easy way to know when the list of selected items in the file browser changes.

### Proposed Solution

Add a new `selectionChanged` signal on the `FileBrowser`. The args could contain the list of selected items or `void` since they can already be retrieved with `browser.selectedItems()`.

### Additional context

This would directly help Notebook 7 in the case of adding buttons to the file browser toolbar when multiple items are selected: https://github.com/jupyter/notebook/pull/6888

Fix incorrect ARIA labels in the `MainAreaWidget`
## References

Issue: https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/issues/13045
PRs: https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/pull/17155, https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/pull/15137

## Code changes

- Changed the aria-label for `content.node` to "main area content" as a more generic default, replacing "notebook content."
- Changed the aria-label for `content.toolbar` to "main area toolbar" as a more useful default, replacing "notebook actions."
- Checked the test to address and correct any instances of improper behavior.

## User-facing changes

Improved ARIA labels for the main content area and toolbar to better reflect their purpose.

## Backwards-incompatible changes

No backwards-incompatible changes identified.

Auto-open uploaded notebook/file after upload
### Problem

When uploading a notebook to work on, it is hard to find it after it was uploaded.

### Proposed Solution

When user uses the upload button either:
- open the uploaded notebook/file
- display a notification with a button allowing to open the notebook/file

Questions:
- a) should we open all file types or only notebooks and text files?
- b) should we display the notification about upload complete for both upload button and drag-and-drop?
- c) when user uploads multiple files should we open them all?
- d) if user uploads a large file which could freeze the UI when opened, should we still open it? Should there be a size limit for auto-open?
- e) should it be opt-in or opt-out?

### Additional context

- Google Colab opens the uploaded notebook straightaway. Colab only allows to upload one notebook at a time.
- Google Drive shows a little notification in the right corner allowing to open the uploaded file or to display its location:
   ![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/d68a3f30-ec46-4567-8d84-826fb710a85a)

Update lumino to `v2025.4.30` to pull menu aria fix

## References

- pulls https://github.com/jupyterlab/lumino/pull/753
- to be released together with https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/pull/17472

CC @nkn2022

## Code changes

Updates to the latest lumino patch.

## User-facing changes

Menu items with a checkmark (e.g. toggled commands) will be announced as checked by screen readers supporting the [`menuitemcheckbox` role](
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Accessibility/ARIA/Reference/Roles/menuitemcheckbox_role)

## Backwards-incompatible changes

None

ARIA labels on main area widget are incorrect (always referring to a notebook)
## Description

https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/blob/b57ec962a7b8cda65bb89a72223f195564f8387a/packages/apputils/src/mainareawidget.ts#L46-L50

says "notebook content" when using a file editor or opening a CSV file, etc, but it should not.

We could:
- change it to "main area content" and "main area toolbar"
- in each of the `MainAreaWidget` subclasses set a proper text
  - we could take the string from a getter so subclasses have less work (getter so that we can translate)
  - if we want to be more strict we could use an abstract getter and force all subclasses of `MainAreaWidget` to provide an aria-label since 4.0

Undo / redo broken in `none` windowing mode
Undo and redo (Cmd + Z, Cmd + Shift + Z on Mac) within a cell is only working on the first cell. I suspect it is caused by `yUndoManager`.

Tested with versions 4.3.4, 4.3.5, 4.4.0a3

Fix document search matching text within unsupported SVG tags
<!--
Thanks for contributing to JupyterLab!
Please fill out the following items to submit a pull request.
See the contributing guidelines for more information:
https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md
-->

## References
Fixes https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/issues/17349

<!-- Note issue numbers this pull request addresses (should be at least one, see contributing guidelines above). -->

<!-- Note any other pull requests that address this issue and how this pull request is different. -->

## Code changes

<!-- Describe the code changes and how they address the issue. -->
I added `svg` in lowercase to the list of unsupported elements, along with some tests and comments that explain why checking the uppercase qualified name for SVG's is not always sufficient to identify an element.
## User-facing changes

<!-- Describe any visual or user interaction changes and how they address the issue. -->
Previously search candidates would match and be highlighted within SVGs which lead to the fragment not rendering and appearing as if it was disappearing.

<!-- For visual changes, include before and after screenshots or GIF/mp4/other video demo here. -->
The disappearing text video can be seen in the original issue, and the following is a video with the proposed changes.

https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/8b01b699-1a7a-43fc-be75-e06476d61870

## Backwards-incompatible changes

<!-- Describe any backwards-incompatible changes to JupyterLab public APIs. -->
I don't believe there should be any backward incompatible changes, however would it make sense to backport this fix?

Obsolete dependency on importlib-resources
The importlib-resources dependency for Python < 3.9 is obsolete because the supported Python versions are >= 3.9

Command palette gets re-rendered even if hidden
## Description

Command palette gets re-rendered even if hidden.

## Reproduce

<!--Describe step-by-step instructions to reproduce the behavior-->

1. Open command palette and two tabs
2. Close the command palette
3. Go to inspector right click on command palette element, select "break on" > "subtree modifications"
4. Switch tabs
5. See that command palette fragments get re-rendered via lumino virtual DOM

![Screenshot from 2022-12-29 13-23-55](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5832902/209961278-164071f9-3032-4091-af3e-84102658cbcb.png)

It is not clear to me why this update appears. Of note the migration to `requestAnimationFrame` in lumino seems to make the debugging/profiling a bit more confusing as I don't immediately see if this was a genuine animation frame request or just lumino messaging.

## Expected behavior

Updating command palette on tab switch is expected because different commands will become available in different contexts (e.g. text editor/notebook), but re-rendering it while it is hidden is not expected.

In a bigger picture we could ask: should command palette get detached rather than hidden. I think hiding is ok because there is ever only one command palette, but requires a better hygiene on when a re-render is triggered.

## Context

- JupyterLab version: 4.0.0a31

HTML sanitizer strips some style attributes breaking custom grid and flexbox layouts ## Description There seems to be an issue with how style attributes are handled in Markdown cells or Markdown documents in JupyterLab. Specifically, custom CSS properties such as grid-template-columns, grid-gap, and flex-direction are not rendered as expected. This makes it impossible to create layouts using CSS for Markdown elements. When trying to use `div` elements with style attributes to create `grid` or `flexbox` layouts, the elements either don't behave as described in the CSS, or the styles appear ignored. Below is an example that demonstrates the issue—it should position elements side by side using CSS Grid or in a column using Flexbox, but the rendered output fails to respect these styles. **Example**: ```html
left Column
right row 1
right row 2
``` Expected behavior: The outer `div` should display two columns within a grid layout, and the inner `div` should stack its child elements (Row 1 and Row 2) vertically with a margin. However, the actual rendered output does not conform to this structure. ## Reproduce: Steps to reproduce the behavior: 1. Open JupyterLab (e.g., version 4.4.0b1). 2. Create a new notebook with a Mardown cell or Markdown document. 3. Add the example HTML/Markdown code provided above into a Markdown cell or document. 4. Render the Markdown content by executing the cell or saving the document. 5. Observe that the styles are not applied correctly. ![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/a2bc885a-9767-41ce-8c62-fbaf271dc797) ## Expected behavior The custom CSS provided in style attributes should be applied correctly to the elements, enabling users to create layouts like grids and flexbox within Markdown cells or documents. The resulting structure should match the defined styles, specifically: The grid layout (grid-template-columns: auto 1fr; grid-gap: 10px) should display two elements side-by-side with a 10px gap between them. The flexbox layout (flex-direction: column; margin-right: 150px) should display child elements stacked vertically with spacing applied as expected. Looking at the rendered output in Chrome DevTools suggests that the issue is related to a sanitizer stripping specific attributes. It appears that even valid style properties are being removed in the rendering pipeline, leading to the described issues. ## Context - Operating System and version: Linux Ubuntu 24.04 - Browser and version: Chrome 134 - JupyterLab version: 4.4.0b1

Fix rendering URLs as linked in errors This PR fixes a bug in error output rendering that prevented URLs from being rendered as HTML links. This bug was introduced when IPython-style file linking was implemented for error output. Here is how URL linking in error output looked in JupyterLab 4.0.x: In JupyterLab 4.3.5, some files are linked, but a nearby URL can cause a file linking to fail. Additionally, URLs are not linked: This PR fixes both of those cases: ## References Fixes #17225 ## Code changes - Changes a broad selector (all `a` tags) to a more narrow selector `a[data-path]` to only do IPython-style file linking for relevant links so that URLs can be linked properly. - Adds a unit test to verify that both URL and file links render properly. - Changes some private functions that returns promises to `async` to simplify them and to reduce the number of immediately-resolving promises. ## User-facing changes **before** (errors highlighted in magenta) **after** ## Backwards-incompatible changes n/a

`stderr` in cell outputs do not auto-link URLs like `stdin` ## Description URLs are automatically linked in the output area of a cell if it is written `stdout` but not if it is written to `stderr`. Here is what it looks like: This rendering is implemented in the `@jupyterlab/rendermime` package for the MIME types `application/vnd.jupyter.stderr` and `application/vnd.jupyter.stdout`: https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/blob/main/packages/rendermime/src/factories.ts#L64-L82 ## Reproduce Create a notebook with a Python kernel and run the following code to see the difference between `stdout` and `stderr`. ```python import sys print("https://example.com/ written to stderr", file=sys.stderr) print("https://example.com/ written to stdout", file=sys.stdout) ``` ## Expected behavior Unless there is some consideration I am missing (perhaps security-related), I would expect the same link handling behavior in both `stdout` and `stderr`. ## Context - Operating System and version: macOS - Browser and version: Chrome 131 - JupyterLab version: 4.4.0a2

`print()` with newline and `end=""` can produce corrupt output
## Description

`print()` with newline and `end=""` can produce corrupt output.

## Reproduce

Create and execute a cell with the following code:

```Python
print("The meaning of life is....\nSome people... ", end="", flush=True)
print("More text.")
```

The output, for me (Jupyter Lab 4.3.4) is
```
The meaning of life is....
More text.e... 
```

I originally discovered this in a cell magic, but it happens when I merely `print()` in a cell.

## Expected behavior

The output should be 
```
The meaning of life is....
Some people... More text.
```

## Context

- Operating System and version: MacOS 15.3.1<!-- e.g. Linux Ubuntu 21.04 -->
- Browser and version: Same behavior, 133.0.6943.126 (Official Build) (arm64), Safari, and Firefox.<!-- e.g. Chrome 92 -->
- JupyterLab version: 4.3.4 <!-- e.g. 3.1.7 -->

Same behavor in Jupyter Version: 7.3.2.

No Browser Output in the JavaScript console.

Request for Accuracy: Rename "Delete" to "Move to Trash"
## Description

In the Jupyterhub UI, the user has the option to "Delete" the file the have selected.
However, the actual behavior of "Delete" is to move the file to $HOME/.local/share/files/Trash

This caused some problems for my team when we wondered why storage space wasn't being cleared after "Delete"ing a file. Renaming this option to "Move to Trash" would be more accurate and mimic what MacOS/Windows names this identical feature.

![Screen Shot 2022-09-22 at 4 38 54 PM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/53441157/191869414-215edc2c-e967-4157-8dce-eb4d87b642e3.png)

## Expected behaviour
We expected "Delete" to delete and clear the storage space that the file once occupied.

## Actual behaviour
"Delete" moves the file to a different location without actually deleting it.

Restart Kernel and Run All Cells is applied on different notebooks if tabs switch in between
## Description

If you have multiple notebooks open and click `Restart Kernel and Run All Cells` for one notebook and switch to another notebook then the kernel restart and run all cells are applied to different notebooks. This must be caused by kernel restart being async and run all cells executing as separated event and recalculating the active tab / notebook. This issue is probably not limited to restart and rerun all, but more combined events that act on active tab.

## Reproduce

It is more easily reproduced if network is slow or kernel restart takes longer.

![jlab restart rerun issue](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/0d5c1e0f-47f4-486c-bbd0-f1c5c6e9f635)

## Expected behavior

Action should be applied to the original notebook / tab

## Context

Tested with JupyterLab version: 4.2.4

Expose `ConfigSection` via a plugin?
### Problem

Currently `@jupyterlite/servives` exposes a `ConfigSection` namespace to interact with the Jupyter Server `/api/config` endpoint: https://jupyter-server.readthedocs.io/en/latest/developers/rest-api.html#get--api-config-section_name

https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/blob/e55daf1f1f6e89ed6b0d72e316d0e4a92805c146/packages/services/src/config/index.ts#L40-L72

Which can be used in other plugins, for example here:

https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/blob/e55daf1f1f6e89ed6b0d72e316d0e4a92805c146/packages/apputils-extension/src/announcements.ts#L72-L74

This functionality is however not exposed the same way as other Jupyter Server and JupyterLab services, such as kernels, sessions, settings, terminals and so on. Which means it's currently not easy to swap the implementation for another one via a plugin, like it is the case now with the `ServiceManagerPlugin` plugins defined here: https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/blob/main/packages/services-extension/src/index.ts

Not sure about the historical reasons for having it exposed this way. But having this config section functionality provided via a plugin sounds like it would be consistent with the other service manager services.

### Proposed Solution

One way could be to expose a new `IConfigSection` token via a `JupyterFrontEndPlugin` providing the same functionality as the current `ConfigSection` namespace by default. In extensions, the plugin providing `IConfigSection` could then be swapped for another implementation.

Another approach would be to add it to the `ServiceManager` interface (and as a `ServiceManagerPlugin`), so it becomes available via `app.serviceManager.config` alongside other Jupyter Server services, and would still be swappable:

https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/blob/e55daf1f1f6e89ed6b0d72e316d0e4a92805c146/packages/services/src/manager.ts#L235-L306

In both cases we can keep backwards compatibility to make sure `ConfigSection.create` is still available, but start encouraging extensions to consume the token (and document it).


### Additional context

This would make it easier for downstream applications and extensions to provide a different backend for storing config sections.

For example in the case of JupyterLite, the config could be stored in the browser (after https://github.com/jupyterlite/jupyterlite/pull/1590).

`ConfigSection.create` is also used in `jupyterlab-tour` here: https://github.com/jupyterlab-contrib/jupyterlab-tour/blob/76f9dbf474cba2748809b13c2654c04909246319/src/plugin.tsx#L63-L68

Fix for issue preventing cell metadata removal
Fixes https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/issues/17164

The root cause was that `setMetadata` method of the `ISharedBaseCell` only overrides the partial metadata (existing keys), rather than replacing the entire metadata.

I have just provided a workaround to ensure the complete removal and replacement of all metadata. However, a more prominent solution would be overriding the `setMetadata` method to ensure it completely replaces the metadata.

Allow customizing the `ServiceManager` with plugins
<!--
Thanks for contributing to JupyterLab!
Please fill out the following items to submit a pull request.
See the contributing guidelines for more information:
https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md
-->

## References

Fixes #15329 
Fixes #12504
Replaces https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/pull/16556
Replaces https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/pull/16783
Closes https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/pull/16141
Depends on https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/pull/16804

More references:
- Based on https://github.com/jupyterlab/lumino/pull/703
- Inspired by https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/pull/13558
- Alternative to #16744 
- Follows a similar approach as in JupyterLite, which registers "server" plugins separately on a different Lumino application (the plugin registry was not usable outside an application before https://github.com/jupyterlab/lumino/pull/703): https://github.com/jupyterlite/jupyterlite/blob/eb0bcb543703213ea883dc1da948ce07494a3148/packages/server-extension/src/index.ts 

<!-- Note issue numbers this pull request addresses (should be at least one, see contributing guidelines above). -->

<!-- Note any other pull requests that address this issue and how this pull request is different. -->

## Motivation

See https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/issues/15329#issue-1967825301

## Code changes

- [x] Update to the latest `@lumino` packages
- [x] Resolve the service manager service first, then start the lab application
- [x] Try with `IDefaultDrive` and `IContentsManager`
- [x] Move all the underlying `ServiceManager` services to their own plugins
- [x] Create a more explicit `ServiceManagerPlugin` plugin type
- [x] ~Use a separate `PluginRegistry` for service manager plugins? Or the same one as regular plugins?~
  - ~A different one clearly separates the two phases of plugin activation~
  - [x] The same one would allow regular plugins to consume service manager plugins, for example requiring `IKernelManager` instead of `app.serviceManager.kernels`. 
- [x] Handle `IConnectionStatus`
- [x] Add a section in the extension dev documentation about "Service Manager Plugins"
- [x] ~Add to the user / developer changelog for visibility?~ Postponing for now
- [x] Create a new `@jupyterlab/services-extension` package to host the service manager plugins
- [x] Mock package test (usage)

This can be tested using this example extension, which disables `@jupyterlab/application-extension:default-drive` and replaces with its own implementation: https://github.com/jtpio/jupyterlab-custom-service-manager-plugins

**Example providing a custom default drive**

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/19511fce-9e77-428b-9e66-15b095941689)

**Example providing a custom `ContentsManager` that logs each `get` call**

```ts
import {
  Contents,
  ContentsManager,
  IContentsManager,
  ServiceManagerPlugin
} from '@jupyterlab/services';

class CustomContents extends ContentsManager {
  async get(
    path: string,
    options?: Contents.IFetchOptions
  ): Promise<Contents.IModel> {
    console.log('CustomContents.get', path);
    return super.get(path, options);
  }
}

const contentsPlugin: ServiceManagerPlugin<Contents.IManager> = {
  id: 'myextension:contents-drive',
  description: 'A JupyterLab extension providing a custom contents manager',
  autoStart: true,
  provides: IContentsManager,
  activate: (_: null): Contents.IManager => {
    console.log('Using a CUSTOM contents manager plugin');
    return new CustomContents();
  }
};

export default [
  contentsPlugin,
];
```

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/9222e69c-cd1a-4f2b-b92e-ad058285202d)

Add run-all-below button to Notebook Panel, becomes gray when starting a new notebook
<!-- Welcome! Thank you for contributing. These HTML comments will not render in the issue.

Before creating a new issue:
* Search for relevant issues
* Follow the issue reporting guidelines:
https://jupyterlab.readthedocs.io/en/latest/getting_started/issue.html
-->

## Description

<!--Describe the bug clearly and concisely. Include screenshots if possible-->

Add the following settings to Notebook Panel as below:
Settings Editor -> Notebook Panel -> Json Settings Editor
```json
{
    "toolbar": [
        {
            "name": "restart-and-run",
            "disabled": true
        },
        {
            "name": "run-all-below",
            "args": {},
            "command": "notebook:run-all-below",
            "icon": "ui-components:fast-forward",
            "disabled": false,
            "rank": 36
        }
    ]
}
```

## Reproduce and Expected behavior

<!--Describe step-by-step instructions to reproduce the behavior-->
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/6d5ab54f-166a-4917-8ffb-c3974871f56e)
Refresh the whole page with F5 before testing the following 3 scenarios:
1. open a new notebook from File Browser, most of the time, the newly added `notebook:run-all-below` icon is gray and not valid to click
2. if u switch to another notebook and switch back, the icon will become valid and clickable
3. if u use web browser's F12 dev mode, most of the time, even if u open new notebook from File Browser, the icon is valid and clickable

<!--Describe how you diagnosed the issue. See the guidelines at
 https://jupyterlab.readthedocs.io/en/latest/getting_started/issue.html -->

Follow-up to #17219

Dropdown for console prompt placement options should be aligned with the button
### Problem

This menu being added in https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/pull/13837 can be all over the place:

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/70359759-b665-490b-8ea5-fa38bb281f69)

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/c5c1c453-bcc4-4709-9de0-ede6206c655b)


### Proposed Solution

For user to be able to anticipate where they need to move their mouse pointer too ideally it would be neatly aligned with the three dots icon. This will be possible with https://github.com/jupyterlab/lumino/pull/732 (we will need to update packages to pull it in)

### Additional context

Alignment is commonly the case see e.g. GNOME:

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/a5d1e3eb-5300-4b02-ae5c-17a0ac00cf26)

GitHub:

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/6a109420-1d8c-4f40-ac48-11c68133da17)

Update to TypeScript 5.8
The last update was for TypeScript 5.1, done in https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/pull/14638.

It would be great to look into updating to the latest version to not lag behind for too long.

In https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/pull/14638#issuecomment-1803584472 @fcollonval said:

> but bumping to 5.2 or later will have some effects as we will need to change the ts configuration.

Looks like this refers to the "module and moduleResolution Must Match Under Recent Node.js settings" section mentioned in https://devblogs.microsoft.com/typescript/announcing-typescript-5-2/#breaking-changes-and-correctness-fixes ?

problem_statement:
PyPI Extension Manager should not show results alphabetically in Discovery
## Description

The discovery section of extensions should not be used for political statements by extension authors gaming the system:

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/0540935b-8847-49f9-be4c-e8fc6464e84e)

Not that the white-blue-red flag is deliberate as it comes from `https://github.com/RussiaZ` account - see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Z_(military_symbol). The one with blue-yellow flag at least is a real extension.

Even worse, someone could use it to show more offensive content.

## Reproduce

Open extension manager

## Expected behavior

- Ideally we would have some popularity or quality sort, but we don't (there was one on npm but not on PyPI)
- Instead let's show extensions from Project Jupyter PyPI org first, then from jupyterlab-contrib and then random.

## Context

- JupyterLab version: 4.x

Current workspace indicator for non-default workspace
### Problem

JupyterLab 4.2.0 includes UI for workspaces (https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/pull/15946), which now can be switched from the sidebar:

![image](https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/assets/5832902/de4c2c7f-93df-49ba-9986-23be2566cbd7)

While it indicates the current workspace with a little checkmark, this is often not visible because the sidebar may be hidden or showing a different panel. Often when switching the workspace the sidebar will go away because the layout of the target workspace may be different.

### Proposed Solution

Show the workspace indicator when the workspace is different from default (and different from an auto-generated workspace?)

For example, one of the earlier designs (https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/issues/6944#issuecomment-649992115) included a workspace switcher in the top bar, next to the menu:

![indicator](https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/assets/5832902/76a02373-0e49-4161-bfbc-e7f147209c2c)

It could be just an indicator, or also a switcher:

![indicator](https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/assets/5832902/f6269128-6225-4e13-b484-b16c46848186)

Alternatively, it could go on the status bar.

### Additional context

Workspace name is often shown on the window title bar, which we already do.

Some applications also show the workspace name in the file browser.

Update to TypeScript 5.8
The last update was for TypeScript 5.1, done in https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/pull/14638.

It would be great to look into updating to the latest version to not lag behind for too long.

In https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/pull/14638#issuecomment-1803584472 @fcollonval said:

> but bumping to 5.2 or later will have some effects as we will need to change the ts configuration.

Looks like this refers to the "module and moduleResolution Must Match Under Recent Node.js settings" section mentioned in https://devblogs.microsoft.com/typescript/announcing-typescript-5-2/#breaking-changes-and-correctness-fixes ?

problem_statement:
`GroupItem` React functional component should allow (and filter out) `null` children ## Description `GroupItem` causes issues when we want to conditionally hide some parts of status bar, see https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/pull/16846#discussion_r1925888221 Because it requires children to be an array of `JSX.Element`: https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/blob/8fbbec937d30b6d87f8ced1259886c2e3a2c8641/packages/statusbar/src/components/group.tsx#L46 but it really should accept any `ReactNode` and just filter out `null`s in: https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/blob/8fbbec937d30b6d87f8ced1259886c2e3a2c8641/packages/statusbar/src/components/group.tsx#L9-L27 Once this is done we should remove any use of `
` which was a workaround.

Fixing dialog closing unexpectedly when typing in the textarea
<!--
Thanks for contributing to JupyterLab!
Please fill out the following items to submit a pull request.
See the contributing guidelines for more information:
https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md
-->

## References

Fixes #14511 
<!-- Note issue numbers this pull request addresses (should be at least one, see contributing guidelines above). -->

<!-- Note any other pull requests that address this issue and how this pull request is different. -->

## Code changes
I've added test in my first commit as told by @krassowski in discussions of this issue. This test is failing which is the expected behaviour for now:

```bash
 ● @jupyterlab/apputils › Dialog › #handleEvent() › keydown › should not accept on enter key within textarea

    expect(received).toBe(expected) // Object.is equality

    Expected: true
    Received: false

      213 |           }
      214 |   
    > 215 |           expect(dialog.isVisible).toBe(true);
          |                                    ^
      216 |   
      217 |           simulate(dialog.node, 'keydown', { key: 'Enter', keyCode: 13 });
      218 |   

      at Object.<anonymous> (test/dialog.spec.tsx:215:36)


 RUNS  test/sessioncontext.spec.ts
```

<!-- Describe the code changes and how they address the issue. -->

## User-facing changes

<!-- Describe any visual or user interaction changes and how they address the issue. -->

<!-- For visual changes, include before and after screenshots or GIF/mp4/other video demo here. -->

## Backwards-incompatible changes

<!-- Describe any backwards-incompatible changes to JupyterLab public APIs. -->

Fix windowing crash due to out-of-bounds access


## References

Alleviates #17227

## Code changes

Check if cell is available before accessing it's model for size estimation.

## User-facing changes

No crash

## Backwards-incompatible changes

None

Changing selected file in file browser is slow
## Description

It can take a couple of seconds to select a file low in the listing, without a mouse, by using <kbd>Down</kbd> in folders with hundreds of files

## Reproduce

1. Open JupyterLab node_modules director
2. Select a folder in the the filebrowser
3. Press arrow down for 3 seconds
4. See the delay in the render state

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/31c6a0fb-227f-4d99-861d-3a2cf39394fc)

Zoomed in:

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/bf5c5c8a-2ffe-4d52-8b5e-84b0fd81c220)

## Expected behavior

No delay.

Basically we should only refresh two items (the one unselected + the one selected), not the entire listing.

In case of multi-selection we should re-render the changed items only as well.

## Context

- Browser and version: Chrome and Firefox
- JupyterLab version: 4.3.0b1

Disappearing notebook due to uncaught exception in estimateWidgetSize
<!-- Welcome! Thank you for contributing. These HTML comments will not render in the issue.

Before creating a new issue:
* Search for relevant issues
* Follow the issue reporting guidelines:
https://jupyterlab.readthedocs.io/en/latest/getting_started/issue.html
-->

## Description

<!--Describe the bug clearly and concisely. Include screenshots if possible-->
Notebook goes "blank" (can't see any of the cells anymore) suddenly when typing into a cell.
It happens because this.widgetCount in getEstimatedTotalSize() is greater than the length of this.cells in this.estimateWidgetSize which ends up throwing a "TypeError: this.cells[e] is undefined" error.

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/8312678d-1480-41f6-946d-760eb3076fa0)

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/7e81be9d-1b3c-4d08-be91-8654340c0dc8)

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/81735233-885a-41c1-ae0a-6af75df905e8)

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/4397897b-b70b-4105-ae8c-4021dcb7c73a)

## Reproduce

<!--Describe step-by-step instructions to reproduce the behavior-->

I have a really hard time reproducing this but I'm somewhat able to in our private JupyterHub instance. Things that I tried that I think might be triggering the described problem is having a lower desktop resolution (I would test at like 1080p with scale above 100%), RTC turned on and having more than one user connected to the same notebook and cells that take up a lot of space (lots of lines). With all of that I can somewhat reproduce it often on our end. When the rendering breaks for one user it'll also break for the other user(s).

This happens with "Windowing Mode" set to "full". When set to "defer" or "none" it'll scroll back to the first cell at the top at position 0.

<!--Describe how you diagnosed the issue. See the guidelines at
 https://jupyterlab.readthedocs.io/en/latest/getting_started/issue.html -->

## Expected behavior

<!--Describe what you expected to happen-->
For the rendering not to randomly break when working in a notebook.

## Context

<!--Complete the following for context, and add any other relevant context-->

- Operating System and version: Windows 11 <!-- e.g. Linux Ubuntu 21.04 -->
- Browser and version: Firefox 128.6.0 or Chrome 132 <!-- e.g. Chrome 92 -->
- JupyterLab version: 4.3.4 <!-- e.g. 3.1.7 -->

Fix emission of `lastCell` from notebook run actions
<!--
Thanks for contributing to JupyterLab!
Please fill out the following items to submit a pull request.
See the contributing guidelines for more information:
https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md
-->

## References

## Code changes

<!-- Describe the code changes and how they address the issue. -->

Minor bugfix resolving issue in actions with accessing last notebook's cell. This PR e.g. enables NotebookActions.selectionExecuted to properly return the information about last cell.

## User-facing changes

<!-- Describe any visual or user interaction changes and how they address the issue. -->

<!-- For visual changes, include before and after screenshots or GIF/mp4/other video demo here. -->

## Backwards-incompatible changes

Flaky UI tests
<!-- Welcome! Thank you for contributing. These HTML comments will not render in the issue.

Before creating a new issue:
* Search for relevant issues
* Follow the issue reporting guidelines:
https://jupyterlab.readthedocs.io/en/latest/getting_started/issue.html
-->

## Description

The `Visual Regression Tests` and `Visual Regression Documentation` CI checks are often flaky, which makes the CI checks appear as failing.

## Reproduce

Example run for https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/pull/14944: https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/actions/runs/5817952284/job/15773457526?pr=14944

![image](https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/assets/591645/e59cfdf5-0345-4786-a953-2dd5f14c79e4)

## Expected behavior

The check should not fail that often, so maintainers can review and merge PRs with more confidence.

## Context

Flaky tests lead to maintenance burden and CI fatigue on maintainers. One has to download the Playwright repo and carefully check the errors to assess whether the failure is related to the change.

Also other maintainers might not feel confident merging PRs if one of the checks is failing (which is understandable).

Update mock packages to not use `jupyter_packaging`
Currently some of the mock packages used in the `usage` tests on CI depend on `jupyter_packaging`: https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/tree/main/jupyterlab/tests/mock_packages

For example:

https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/blob/87cb79fe29c623f1e2f3d00e8d0d51c656ef12d4/jupyterlab/tests/mock_packages/test-hyphens/setup.py#L21

However `jupyter_packaging` is not maintained anymore, in favor of https://github.com/jupyterlab/hatch-jupyter-builder.

So it would be great to update these mock packages to `hatch-jupyter-builder`.

Disabling fuzzy filtering in file browser does not work
## Description

Disabling fuzzy filtering in the file browser does not work.

## Reproduce

<!--Describe step-by-step instructions to reproduce the behavior-->

1. Create files named "test" and "tst"
2. Filter for "tst"
3. See both are shown (ok)
4. Open Settings Editor, go to File Browser
5. Unclick "Filter on file name with a fuzzy search"
6. Filter again
7. See both are still shown

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/3b0382d7-f90f-4474-9809-e75a6890a8e5)

The value is hardcoded here: https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/blob/1f6f64bbd56bc9363315114a4fe0f642252ef464/packages/filebrowser/src/browser.ts#L106

## Expected behavior

Only tst shows up.

## Context

- Browser and version: Chrome
- JupyterLab version: 4.3.x and 4.4.0a2

Browser tab's name doesn't get updated if Lab is opened in simple mode
## Description

If JupyterLab is opened using `/doc` URL (i.e. in simple mode) the tab name does not update when switching between documents. It looks like this is more reliably reproducible if there is a workspace redirection happening.

This does not happen if JupyterLab is opened in normal mode with `/lab` and then switched to simple mode.

## Reproduce

1. Create an `A.ipynb` and `B.ipynb`
2. Open http://127.0.0.1:8888/doc/tree/A.ipynb
3. Switch between notebooks
4. See browser title does **not** update

https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/777474c1-c416-4ccd-ab72-eedab11b4e95

## Expected behavior

It works the same way as it works:

In normal mode:

6. Open http://127.0.0.1:8888/lab/tree/A.ipynb
7. Switch between notebooks
8. See browser title does update

In simple mode if lab was loaded with normal mode:

9. Open http://127.0.0.1:8888/lab/tree/A.ipynb
10. Switch mode to simple
11. Switch between notebooks
12. See browser title does update

https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/6398ca82-aea3-4cea-9c40-203b2d0e8a15


## Context

- Browser and version: Chrome
- JupyterLab version: 4.3.4, 4.4.0a2

Update to TypeScript 5.8
The last update was for TypeScript 5.1, done in https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/pull/14638.

It would be great to look into updating to the latest version to not lag behind for too long.

In https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/pull/14638#issuecomment-1803584472 @fcollonval said:

> but bumping to 5.2 or later will have some effects as we will need to change the ts configuration.

Looks like this refers to the "module and moduleResolution Must Match Under Recent Node.js settings" section mentioned in https://devblogs.microsoft.com/typescript/announcing-typescript-5-2/#breaking-changes-and-correctness-fixes ?

+TypeScript update
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+As a follow-up to the update to TypeScript 5.2, the ``tsconfig.json`` configuration of the ``@jupyterlab/buildutils`` package changed
+the ``module`` option from ``commonjs`` to ``Node16``:
+
+.. code:: diff
+
+   index 7095bede4bd5..8c5bff0d45d8 100644
+   --- a/buildutils/tsconfig.json
+   +++ b/buildutils/tsconfig.json
+   @@ -3,7 +3,7 @@
+     "compilerOptions": {
+       "outDir": "lib",
+       "rootDir": "src",
+   -   "module": "commonjs",
+   +   "module": "Node16",
+       "moduleResolution": "node16"
+     },
+     "include": ["src/*"],
+

problem_statement:
Fix "running" prompt state with server-side execution
## References

- Follow up to https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/pull/16651

## Code changes

- [x] Adds a test demonstrating an issue where the `execution_count` being reset incorrectly overrode the execution state, resulting in no `[*]` prompt in the interface but instead only `[ ]`
- [x] Fixes the issue by not changing `execution_count` when provided with the value of `null`

## User-facing changes

`[*]` shows up correctly when using server-side exeuction

## Backwards-incompatible changes

None

Cannot remove cell metadata
## Description

Once the Cell metadata is modified with new attributes, it becomes impossible to remove any added attribute.

## Reproduce

1. In a notebook, create a Markdown cell
2. While this cell is selected, open the Property Inspector
3. Expand the Advanced Tools pane
4. Under Cell metadata, between `{}`, enter something like `"lang": "en"`
5. Click the check mark button.
6. Delete everything between `{}`. Click again the check mark button
7. Collapse the Advanced Tools pane
8. Expand the Advanced Tools pane

The attribute `"lang": "en"` is back.

9. Expand the Common Tools pane

The Cell metadata is now filled with the defaults of the Common Tools.

10. Delete everything again. Click again the check mark button
11. Collapse and Expand the Advanced Tools pane

All deleted attributes are back.

## Expected behavior

When valid metadata are saved through the Advanced Tools, nothing should overwrite what is saved by the check mark button. In the above examples, when all metadata are deleted, it should remain deleted.

## Context

- Operating System and version: Windows 11 Pro, version 24H2
- Browser and version: Firefox 134.0
- JupyterLab version: 4.3.4

The svg(+) next to add tag is misaligned

## Description
Misaligned svg of the add tag

## Reproduce

1. select a cell
2. go to property inspector
3. the svg next to add is misalinged

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/98e1d60e-c3e3-4c82-8215-ffc268ce68a1)

## Expected behavior

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/442b357f-32e9-46dd-b3ee-941edb325cb2)

Code colors have insufficient contrast
<!-- Welcome! Thank you for contributing. These HTML comments will not render in the issue.

Before creating a new issue:
* Search for relevant issues
* Follow the issue reporting guidelines:
https://jupyterlab.readthedocs.io/en/latest/getting_started/issue.html
-->

## Description

Some colors used to render code in both Light and Dark Theme don't have enough contrast vs background (should be 7:1)

![contrast](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/93281816/226788366-585d2a2d-c205-4d60-8820-75093d9f8374.png)

This was found during a bug bash by @andrii-i .

Read-only cells become editable when changing notebook settings programatically
## Description

Read-only cells become editable when changing notebook settings programatically. This approach is used to change `autoStartDefaultKernel` in core JupyterLab by clicking "Always start the preferred kernel" checkbox. Changing settings manually does not lead to this problem.

This was originally reported for [jupyterlab-execute-time](https://github.com/deshaw/jupyterlab-execute-time/issues/107) which changes `recordTiming` programatically.

## Reproduce

1. Open a notebook, select a cell
2. Open property inspector, switch cell to "Read-Only"
3. Click on kernel selector
4. Check "Always start the preferred kernel" in the dialog
5. Accept
6. See that the cell can be edited despite the metadata still forbidding it

![breaks-read-only](https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/assets/5832902/9f18ba88-e067-439c-a4b1-e3d08df8a1c6)

## Expected behavior

Cells stay read-only when notebook settings are changed programatically.

## Context

- JupyterLab version: 4.0.9 and 4.1.0a4

<details>

<summary>Stack trace</summary>

![image](https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/assets/5832902/9eb7603e-d0d0-4a0f-8e50-ea80082a8770)

</details>

Search highlight is not applied for matches on Python builtin keywords
## Description

Similar to https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/pull/17065 but down to higher specificity of

https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/blob/6e1174e202b6bf5a7b725d59b5ddafc5f0afbed2/packages/codemirror/src/theme.ts#L86-L88

added in https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/pull/15805

## Reproduce

<!--Describe step-by-step instructions to reproduce the behavior-->

1. Type `from x import y`
2. Change theme to light/dark/high contrast dark
3. Search for `"m"
4. See poor contrast due to green not being replaced by search highlight color

## Expected behavior

Syntax highlighting is overwritten correctly

## Context

- JupyterLab version: 4.3.2

Dialog closes unexpectedly when typing in the textarea
<!-- Welcome! Thank you for contributing. These HTML comments will not render in the issue.

Before creating a new issue:
* Search for relevant issues
* Follow the issue reporting guidelines:
https://jupyterlab.readthedocs.io/en/latest/getting_started/issue.html
-->

## Description

I'm working on a JupyterLab extension where I need to create a Dialog containing a `textarea` and several `input` boxes. I have implemented a custom class that `extends ReactWidget and implements Dialog.IBodyWidget<ReactWidget>`. I pass an instance of this class as the body parameter to the `showDialog` function. The dialog mechanism is functioning correctly, but I'm encountering an issue with the `textarea`. Whenever I click inside the `textarea`, type some text, and press "enter", it automatically closes the dialog as if I had pressed the "ok" button. I suspect this issue is related to event listeners.

## Reproduce

1. Create a new dialog class (I used: `extends ReactWidget and implements Dialog.IBodyWidget<ReactWidget>`).
2. In the `render(): JSX.Element` method add some `textarea`.
3. Try to add text into the `textarea` and then press "enter".

## Expected behavior

It should just add a new line instead of closing the dialog.

## Context

<!--Complete the following for context, and add any other relevant context-->

- Operating System and version: Linux 5.14.21
- Browser and version: Chrome 112
- JupyterLab version: 3.6.3

Fix sanitizer call in ToC if html data is array of strings
<!--
Thanks for contributing to JupyterLab!
Please fill out the following items to submit a pull request.
See the contributing guidelines for more information:
https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md
-->

## References

<!-- Note issue numbers this pull request addresses (should be at least one, see contributing guidelines above). -->
Fixes https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/issues/16856

<!-- Note any other pull requests that address this issue and how this pull request is different. -->

## Code changes

<!-- Describe the code changes and how they address the issue. -->
If the HTML data is an array of strings (e.g. as plotly generates it), the data is joined).

## User-facing changes

<!-- Describe any visual or user interaction changes and how they address the issue. -->

<!-- For visual changes, include before and after screenshots or GIF/mp4/other video demo here. -->
No.

## Backwards-incompatible changes

<!-- Describe any backwards-incompatible changes to JupyterLab public APIs. -->
No.

The `query` argument in `settingeditor:open` does not update query when Settings Editor is already open
## Description

Extensions can open the settings editor on a given setting by passing a `query` argument. It works great when the Settings Editor is closed, but if it is already open, the command switches to the Settings Editor tab but ignores the `query` argument.

## Reproduce

This is because of the short-circuit logic in:

https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/blob/130089eddb330a44f7f9d496b1e64eddcb497d6b/packages/settingeditor-extension/src/index.ts#L115-L143

which only calls activate but does not update `query` from `args.query`.

## Expected behavior

The query is respected on second and consecutive executions on `settingeditor:open` command.

## Context

- JupyterLab version: 4.2.2

HTML Sanitizer problem/crash
It may be a problem with Plotly, and I should file an issue there.
However, I am observing a crash in the HTML sanitizer. It says `this.buffer.charCodeAt` is not a function.
The cause is relatively easy to find. Plotly generates HTML lines, which are an array of strings. The HTML sanitizer only allows strings (with the charCodeAt). This issue is probably relatively rare, as it only occurs when I have not installed Plotly in my development environment, and so the HTML code is usually not rendered.
You can reproduce it by creating a notebook with Plotly plots, saving it, and opening it in a clean environment without Plotly.

Nothing really important.

Fix consecutive invocations of inline completion
<!--
Thanks for contributing to JupyterLab!
Please fill out the following items to submit a pull request.
See the contributing guidelines for more information:
https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md
-->

## References

<!-- Note issue numbers this pull request addresses (should be at least one, see contributing guidelines above). -->
Fixes #17011
<!-- Note any other pull requests that address this issue and how this pull request is different. -->

## Code changes

<!-- Describe the code changes and how they address the issue. -->
Apply inline completion suggestion and cursor position update in the same codemirror transaction to avoid document change listener react with a wrong editor position.

This is therefore done using codemirror mechanism and not the shared model.

> I checked that the changes are still applied as single change for the undo manager.

## User-facing changes

<!-- Describe any visual or user interaction changes and how they address the issue. -->
Continuous inline completion works as expected.

https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/5e88a457-6cb6-4f3c-b2bb-6e4b2e18f54a

<!-- For visual changes, include before and after screenshots or GIF/mp4/other video demo here. -->

<!-- Describe any backwards-incompatible changes to JupyterLab public APIs. -->
None

Settings Editor Form Values Not Updating After Indirect Setting Changes
<!-- Welcome! Thank you for contributing. These HTML comments will not render in the issue.

Before creating a new issue:
* Search for relevant issues
* Follow the issue reporting guidelines:
https://jupyterlab.readthedocs.io/en/latest/getting_started/issue.html
-->

## Description

<!--Describe the bug clearly and concisely. Include screenshots if possible-->
When modifying settings through the JSON Settings Editor, the changes are applied, but the corresponding values in the Settings Editor form do not update until the page is refreshed.

## Reproduce

<!--Describe step-by-step instructions to reproduce the behavior-->

1. Go to settings editor
2. Click on JSON Settings Editor
3. Modify a setting, such as the theme, by adding a new value in the `User Preferences` section. For example:
```bash
{
    "theme": "JupyterLab Dark"
}
```
5. Save the settings
6. Observe that the applied setting (e.g., the dark theme) takes effect, but the form in the Settings Editor still shows the previous value (e.g. Jupyter Light).

FIM (fill in the middle) support for inline completer on typing
### Problem

_Fill-in-the-middle_ allows to add code in the middle of the code line. This is currently supported when manually invoking the inline completer, but it is not possible for user to get inline completion suggestions automatically when typing in the middle of the line (these are only returned at the end of the line); this is codified in:

https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/blob/bb596b37d44cacb7aaec2c09aa5d6c8b43a3a2a8/packages/completer/src/handler.ts#L467-L473

### Proposed Solution

Add an opt-in option allowing for inline completion to be auto-triggered when anywhere in the line.

Of note, the manual invoke is allowed anywhere since https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/pull/16298 included `4.1.x`.

### Additional context

Quoting the Codeium [blog post](https://codeium.com/blog/inline-fim-code-suggestions) (emphasis mine):

> This scenario where there is text on both sides of the cursor (on the same line) and we want autocomplete suggestions is a special case of the fill-in-the-middle task called in-line fill-in-the-middle, or in-line FIM for short. **And it is not easy to get in-line FIM to work well enough to be helpful rather than distracting.**
> 
> [...]
> So what is likely going on with these AI code assistants? In the original post, we showed how TabNine didn’t have generic FIM capabilities in the first place. Amazon CodeWhisperer on face value does, but they must have made some significant fundamental errors in building FIM since the suggestions are quite poor, error-prone, and often not referencing post-cursor context.
> 
> But what about Github Copilot? They have reasonable FIM suggestions for filling in lines and using future context, so why is in-line FIM not enabled? Honestly, we are not sure. Copilot has normal FIM suggestions and it seems like there shouldn’t be anything that is stopping it from exposing in-line FIM suggestions. Our guess is that they tried to enable in-line FIM, but the performance wasn’t good enough, maybe from a lack of in-line FIM-like training examples or some other training knobs. All we know is that for now, Copilot has not enabled in-line FIM in production, and likely that means there is something up with the underlying model, which they are unwilling to retrain, or their FIM handling capabilities are inherently worse.


This appears like a good enough rationale for making it opt-in in JupyterLab rather than opt-out, especially because compared to GitHub Copilot or Codeium, JupyterLab does not have a set of curated supported models for which pre-processing and context provision is fine-tuned to return good enough in-line FIM to be more useful than distracting.

---

Previously a broader question about FIM was opened in https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/issues/16671 but it did not contain specific change requests - only a question about support status.

--- 

LSP specification does not have a special trigger kind or metadata for in-line FIM.

Printing carriage return (\r) from external (c++) python module screws text-out ## Description This is a followup of https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/issues/16995. While https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/pull/16999 fixed the carriage return for the python print statement, I still get issues with \r based progressbars created in a c++ module (exposed via pybind11). Printing \r from a pybind11 module seems to screw up consecutive printing calls in the respective cell. The python print statement itself is not affected and seems to work fine since https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/pull/16999. Still, I believe that this is a regression related to https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/pull/16999 and not to pybind11, because a) this worked fine in 4.2.6 and b) I can use e.g. xeus-cling without pybind11 to reproduce this issue ## Reproduce Here I xeus-cling to to run the following code cells (e.g. mamba install -c conda-forge jupyterlab xeus-cling). Compiling a pybind11 module and calling the exposed function from jupyterlab produces the exact same results. Here are 2 code examples to explain the problem: ## Example 1: progress loop ``` #import #import using namespace std; cout << "-- begin --" << endl; for (size_t i=0; i <100; ++i){ cout << "Progress: " << i << "\r" << flush; } cout << endl; cout << "-- end --" << endl; ``` ### Expected result (and result when using jupyterlab==4.2.6 ``` -- begin -- Progress: 99 -- end -- ``` ### Result for jupyterlab==4.3.1 ``` -- begin -- Progress: 0Progress: 1Progress: 2Progress: 3Progress: 4Progress: 5Progress: 6Progress: 7Progress: 8Progress: 9Progress: 10Progress: 11Progress: 12Progress: 13Progress: 14Progress: 15Progress: 16Progress: 17Progress: 18Progress: 19Progress: 20Progress: 21Progress: 22Progress: 23Progress: 24Progress: 25Progress: 26Progress: 27Progress: 28Progress: 29Progress: 30Progress: 31Progress: 32Progress: 33Progress: 34Progress: 35Progress: 36Progress: 37Progress: 38Progress: 39Progress: 40Progress: 41Progress: 42Progress: 43Progress: 44Progress: 45Progress: 46Progress: 47Progress: 48Progress: 49Progress: 50Progress: 51Progress: 52Progress: 53Progress: 54Progress: 55Progress: 56Progress: 57Progress: 58Progress: 59Progress: 60Progress: 61Progress: 62Progress: 63Progress: 64Progress: 65Progress: 66Progress: 67Progress: 68Progress: 69Progress: 70Progress: 71Progress: 72Progress: 73Progress: 74Progress: 75Progress: 76Progress: 77Progress: 78Progress: 79Progress: 80Progress: 81Progress: 82Progress: 83Progress: 84Progress: 85Progress: 86Progress: 87Progress: 88Progress: 89Progress: 90Progress: 91Progress: 92Progress: 93Progress: 94Progress: 95Progress: 96Progress: 97Progress: 98Progress: 99 -- end -- ``` ### Result for jupyterlab==4.3.2 ``` -- begin -- -- end -- 9 ``` ## Example 2: consecutive print statements It seems that this error is related to the cursor position handling in v4.3.2. Before calling "cout << endl" the code actually produces "Progress: 99" in jupyterlab 4.3.2. However, calling cout << endl; deletes the current line and than copies part of the line to the end of the cell. Take the following code block ``` #import using namespace std; cerr << "--0123456789-ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOP--\r" << flush; cerr << endl; cerr << "Second" << endl; ``` ### Expected result (jupyterlab 4.2.6 AND 4.3.1) ``` --0123456789-ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOP-- Second ``` ### Result jupyterlab 4.3.2 ``` Second 6789-ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOP-- ``` (Notice the empty line at the beginning of the 4.3.2 output) The behavior that part of the '\r' text is copied to the end of the cell is carried forth with consecutive print statements. Take the following code: ``` #import using namespace std; cerr << "--0123456789-ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOP--\r" << flush; cerr << endl; cerr << "Second" << endl; cerr << "third" << endl; ``` ### Result Jupyterlab 4.3.2 ``` Second third BCDEFGHIJKLMNOP-- ``` The behavior that part of the \r line is moved to the end of the cell continues even when calling \r from a pybind11 module and then calling print() from within python. ## Example 3: using python loop only For completenes, the following loop produces the correct results in jupyterlab 4.2.6 and 4.3.2 ``` print("-- begin --") for i in range(100): print('Progress:',i,end='\r') print() print("-- end --") ``` The python print statement is thus not affected. ## Context - Operating System and version: Linux Ubuntu 24.04 (Likely operation system independent) - JupyterLab version: e.g. 4.3.2 - See also this bug: https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/issues/16995

Fix emission of `FileBrowserModel.onFileChanged` for drives (including `RTC:`)
## References

Fixes https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyter-collaboration/issues/406.

## Code changes

When an operation is made on a file, we emit a signal if the file is in the current directory, which may trigger a refresh of the directory content. For instance, if a file is created, it immediately appears in the file browser, instead of after the next poll.
To check if the file is in the current directory, we compare the current file browser path with the path of the file. Both may have a drive prefix (e.g. `RTC:`). To get the directory of the file, we use `PathExt.dirname()` which seems to strip the drive prefix. But the current file browser path has the drive prefix, so the outcome is that we always think that the file is not in the current directory.
This PR removes the drive prefix of the current file browser path when making this comparison.

## User-facing changes

Operations such as creating a file or uploading a file look immediate in the file browser, for custom drives that have a prefix.
## Backwards-incompatible changes

None.

Fix total size estimation in full windowing mode to reduce scrollbar jitter
## References

Alleviates issues caused by the rendered outputs or cells changing height:
- https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/issues/16326
- https://github.com/jupyter-book/jupyterlab-myst/issues/243

## Code changes

1) Previously if height of a cell in the middle of the notebook changed then the sizes and offsets of all subsequent cells were discarded. After change the offset delta is instead computed and subsequent sizes and offsets are adjusted rather than being discarded.

2) Previously the size estimates were only stored after the viewport window was moved away from initial null position; this constraint was now reduced to also store sizes when windowing is active but window size has not been computed yet.

3) Previously if new cell was added  (or a cell was removed/type of a cell was changed) the height estimates were discarded for the purpose of scrollbar size calculation; with this PR this is no longer the case (3341517)

## User-facing changes

Before this change the total scrollbar length was reset after changing height of any cell other than the last. This was causing very jittrery scroll as the scrollbar height was changing as the notebook was scrolled.

Support kernel subshells (JEP91)
[Jupyter Enhancement Proposal 91](https://github.com/ipython/ipykernel/pull/1249) was recently accepted, introducing the idea of kernel subshells which are separate threads of execution running in the same process and hence share the same namespace. An example of their use would be when running a long calculation one could create a new subshell to check on progress in that calculation. IPyKernel `main` branch contains a minimal implementation of kernel subshells (ipython/ipykernel#1249) that is backward compatible and will be included in the upcoming IPyKernel 7 release. Hopefully there will be an alpha release available soon (ipython/ipykernel#1274) for testing purposes.

I propose to make kernel subshell functionality available in JupyterLab so that developers and end users can experiment with it. The idea is that the context menu for a running kernel notebook or console will include an option to create a new subshell of that kernel in a new console. There is a primitive video of this at https://github.com/jupyter/enhancement-proposals/pull/91#issuecomment-1924380771 (although the surrounding discussion is somewhat out of date).

I intend to add a new boolean flag (`--LabApp.kernel_subshells` perhaps) which is `False` by default so that devs/users will have to explicitly opt into the new functionality, and if `False` there will be no change to existing UI and behaviour. Kernels self-advertise their support for subshells by including `supported_features: ['kernel subshells']` in their `kernel_info_reply` messages ([JEP92](https://github.com/jupyter/enhancement-proposals/pull/92)), and again without that there will be no change to existing UI and behaviour for a particular kernel.

`IKernelConnection` will need a new optional string attribute `subshellId`, this will be `null` (or `undefined`) for the main subshell. For a subshell this is in the reply to a `create_subshell_request` message. The `subshellId` is an optional parameter of e.g. `execute_request` messages to indicate which subshell the code should be run in.

I am starting work on this straight away. If anyone needs any clarification then please don't hesitate to ask.

## Code changes

The autosave feature works by starting a timer.  When the timer expires, it clears itself; then, if the session is connected, it attempts a save (which then restarts the timer for the next save).  However, if the session is disconnected, the timer never gets restarted - this code just calls `_setTimer()` in that case.

Export custom settings to an `overrides.json` from the Settings Editor
<!-- Welcome! Thank you for contributing. These HTML comments will not render in the issue, but you can delete them once you've read them if you prefer! -->

<!--
Thanks for thinking of a way to improve JupyterLab. If this solves a problem for you, then it probably solves that problem for lots of people! So the whole community will benefit from this request.


Before creating a new feature request please search the issues for relevant feature requests.
-->

### Problem

Currently it can be quite a bit of work to construct an [`overrides.json`](https://jupyterlab.readthedocs.io/en/latest/user/directories.html#overrides-json) file by hand.

If a user would then like to encode this set of custom settings in a config file, it can become quite tedious to find the values and copy them by hand to an `overrides.json`.

### Proposed Solution

Sometimes the good set of custom settings is found by trial and error, by modifying the settings via the Settings Editor, and see what effect they have in JupyterLab.

It could be useful to have a button to export the list of custom settings to an `overrides.json`, for example on the left side of the settings editor toolbar:

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/9c12717d-3d99-4468-86b1-71ead44ae485)


### Additional context

Some comments in the following two issues seem to be talking about such export functionality:

- https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/issues/8148
- https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/pull/11079

Better handling of the file browser configuration
<!-- Welcome! Thank you for contributing. These HTML comments will not render in the issue.

Before creating a new issue:
* Search for relevant issues
* Follow the issue reporting guidelines:
https://jupyterlab.readthedocs.io/en/latest/getting_started/issue.html
-->

## Description

Currently the file browser sets its own default config here:

https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/blob/d98ef15bfa916309c82d105a5d442d915d5dd1df/packages/filebrowser-extension/src/index.ts#L219-L247

Since this happens at application startup, it can override other configuration set in different plugins.


## Reproduce

In a separate plugin (for example in a custom third-party extension), use `browser.showFileCheckboxes = true` to show the file browser checkboxes by default on application startup.

However because of the current logic with the code snippet above the default configuration will be applied again when the plugin activates.

In the following screencast we see how the checkboxes first appear and then quickly disappear:

https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/assets/591645/0c7dc958-2fba-4441-81ef-86db77f26002



## Expected behavior

Other plugins should be allowed to use public setters like `browser.showFileCheckboxes = true` to customize the behavior of the file browser, when there is no user setting available.

If there is a value in the settings, then it takes precedence.

## Context

This is an issue in Notebook 7 which has to use the settings to store its default values for the file browser (checkboxes, file size column, sort notebooks first). For example: https://github.com/jupyter/notebook/pull/6892

However since these settings are also shared with JupyterLab, they also apply in the JupyterLab interface.

The idea would be for Notebook 7 to be able to customize with the following without having the configuration being overridden by the default lab plugin:

```ts
browser.showFileCheckboxes = true
browser.sortNotebookFirst = true
browser.showFileSizeColumn = true
```

I reported this issue upstream at https://github.com/codemirror/dev/issues/1454 and found upgrading @lezer/python dependency resolved this.

## Expected behavior
Bracket highlighting works properly

- Browser and version: JupyterLab Desktop 4.2.5-1 (latest)

Incorrect disposal of LSP connection due to access to undefined `serverRequests`
## Description

Sometimes when switching kernels I see an uncaught error:

```ts
connection.ts:271 Uncaught (in promise) TypeError: Cannot convert undefined or null to object
    at Function.values (<anonymous>)
    at LSPConnection.dispose (connection.ts:271:12)
    at DocumentConnectionManager.unregisterDocument (connection_manager.ts:428:20)
    at NotebookAdapter.disconnect (adapter.ts:304:30)
    at NotebookAdapter.reloadConnection (adapter.ts:397:10)
    at NotebookAdapter.onKernelChanged (notebooklspadapter.ts:209:12)
```

This is raised from:

https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/blob/2ceabd8c7b98e7b2c305be406ade799f387a90eb/packages/lsp/src/connection.ts#L267-L273

and happens because `serverRequests` have no initializer in constructor nor in class definition: 

https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/blob/2ceabd8c7b98e7b2c305be406ade799f387a90eb/packages/lsp/src/connection.ts#L229-L232

These are only initialized after server initialization in `afterInitialized`:
 
https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/blob/2ceabd8c7b98e7b2c305be406ade799f387a90eb/packages/lsp/src/connection.ts#L481-L483


## Expected behavior

- Disposal of connections which have not yet initialized does not raise an error.
- There is a unit test case for this scenario

## Context

- JupyterLab version: 4.1.5

Cannot open notebooks with stream in outputs in JupyterLab 4.3.0b0-1
## Description

A critical performance regression in JupyterLab 4.3.0b0 was identified in testing: notebooks with large amount of stream data in outputs no longer open in reasonable time.

While users are reporting that notebooks do not open at all, it appears that the time opening a notebook is now a quadratic or exponential function of stream data content, which may indicate that some previously functional notebooks will not open before the heat death of the universe.

This was most likely:
- introduced in https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/pull/16498, and
- not fixed by https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/pull/16692

CC @davidbrochart

## Reproduce


1. Download the attached notebook [50_char_500_lines.json](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/17131015/50_char_500_lines.json) file
2. Rename it to `50_char_500_lines.ipynb` - it has only one code cell and only one output
3. Open it in JupyterLab 4.3
4. See that it takes 10-15 seconds to open (depending on the browser)

The single output of the cell looks like this:

```js
{
     "name": "stdout",
     "output_type": "stream",
     "text": [
         "aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaa\n",
         /* of different lengths, repated many times */
         "aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaa\n"
     ]
}
```

Timings in Chrome:
- 50 characters repeated in 100 lines took 0.3s to load
- 50 characters repeated in 200 lines took 1.4s to load
- 50 characters repeated in 500 lines took 8s to load
- 50 characters repeated in 1000 lines took 30s to load

Timings in Firefox:
- 50 characters repeated in 500 lines took 15s to load
- 50 characters repeated in 1000 lines took 93s to load

I have not tested Safari but I would expect even worse timings.

## Expected behavior

Notebooks opens as fast as in JupyterLab 4.2 (or faster) where even the test notebook with 1000 lines takes **less than one second** to open.

## Context

- Browser: Chrome and Firefox
- JupyterLab version: 4.3.0b0 and 4.3.0b1

Here is the relevant flame graph:

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/306cf581-16f6-4aa7-b680-9a75ad34cd06)

problem_statement:
Find & replace function also replaces text in read-only cells
For details please refer to the issue in the notebook repo: https://github.com/jupyter/notebook/issues/7431 which can be reproduced in Jupyterlab as well.

@RRosio forwarded me here.

Could also be related: https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/issues/15514

The type of a non-editable cell can be changed
## Description

The type of cells with "editable": false can be changed (e.g. from Code to Markdown or Raw).


## Reproduce

In a new notebook, edit metadata adding  

    "editable": false

the cell cannot be edited, but it is possible to change its type from the toolbar.

## Expected behavior

It should not be possible to change the type, as in jupyter notebook.

## Context

Reproduced in a clean env (conda create -n jlab-test --override-channels --strict-channel-priority -c conda-forge -c nodefaults jupyterlab)

JupyterLab Version 3.1.13
Google Chrome | 93.0.4577.82
Windows 10 OS Version 2009
JavaScript | V8 9.3.345.19

I was NOT able to reproduce the problem in Jupyter notebook.

Optimize SVG icons from `@jupyterlab/ui-components` and update SVGO config Hi! 👋 ### Problem While there have been efforts in the past to clean up the SVG icons available in [`@jupyterlab/ui-components`](https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/tree/67cb8f8347f13d52dc100f33fb532acbf36b3b23/packages/ui-components/style/icons) and keep them as small as possible, it is still possible to further optimize them (as well as keep them consistent in terms of indentation, attribute order, etc.). By doing so, either by minifying the SVG icons or pretty printing them via SVGO, as well as via some manual adjustments, it is possible to reduce the size of most icons (there are some cases where this reduction is to about half of the original size). This reduction also affects the respective packaged JS file served by JupyterLab (since SVG files are _stringified_ and included in the bundle): ### Proposed Solution To optimize the SVG icons, I think there are three tasks that can be done: 1. Update the SVGO configuration and the respective command in the `package.json` file (see the snippet below). The YAML format is no longer supported since [SVGO 2.0.0](https://github.com/svg/svgo/releases/tag/v2.0.0). 2. Run SVGO to optimize the current icons. I would suggest minifying them as much as possible by removing [`js2svg` from the configuration](https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/blob/67cb8f8347f13d52dc100f33fb532acbf36b3b23/packages/ui-components/svgo.yaml#L70-L76), but pretty printing them works too. 3. Remove attribute values ​​and unnecessary SVG elements manually from some icons: - Some icons, like the [`yaml.svg` icon](https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/blob/67cb8f8347f13d52dc100f33fb532acbf36b3b23/packages/ui-components/style/icons/filetype/yaml.svg), have Adobe Illustrator classes (`st*` classes) that can be removed, if I'm correct. - Some icons, like the [`error.svg` icon](https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/blob/67cb8f8347f13d52dc100f33fb532acbf36b3b23/packages/ui-components/style/icons/error.svg), have an invisible placeholder element (``) to define, I believe, the desired frame/size for the final icon. This element can also be removed as the desired frame for the icon is maintained. This result can also be obtained via an SVGO plugin: `{ name: "removeUselessStrokeAndFill", params: { stroke: true, fill: true, removeNone: true } }`. ```json "scripts": { "cleansvg": "svgo --folder style/icons --recursive" } ``` ### Additional context - Operating System and version: macOS Sonoma 14.5 - Browser and version: Chrome 127.0.6533.89 - JupyterLab version: 4.3.0a2 - Python version: 3.10.13 - Related issues/PRs: - https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/issues/16673 - https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/pull/16666 Let me know what you think and if I can open a PR. Thanks!

diff --git a/packages/ui-components/package.json b/packages/ui-components/package.json
index cb5473c0b8eb..b17e65c163e1 100644
--- a/packages/ui-components/package.json
+++ b/packages/ui-components/package.json
@@ -31,7 +31,7 @@
     "build": "tsc -b",
     "build:test": "tsc --build tsconfig.test.json",
     "clean": "rimraf lib && rimraf tsconfig.tsbuildinfo",
-    "cleansvg": "svgo --config svgo.yaml",
+    "clean:svg": "svgo --folder style/icons --recursive",
     "docs:init": "bash docs/build.sh",
     "test": "jest",
     "test:cov": "jest --collect-coverage",
@@ -68,7 +68,7 @@
     "@types/react": "^18.0.26",
     "jest": "^29.2.0",
     "rimraf": "~5.0.5",
-    "svgo": "^3.0.1",
+    "svgo": "^3.3.2",
     "typescript": "~5.1.6"
   },
   "peerDependencies": {
